author: John J. Moser
title: Comedian Bill Burr, known for TV specials and 'Breaking Bad' role, to play Sands Bethlehem Event Center
text:
A comedian who got his big break on Dave Chappell’s “Chappell Show,” is known for his TV comedy specials and who had a recurring role on the acclaimed AMC-TV crime drama “Breaking Bad” is coming to Sands Bethlehem Event Center, it was just announced.
Bill Burr, known for his 2010 “Let it Go” special on Comedy Central and 2012 special “You People Are All The Same” on Netflix, will perform at the event center at 8 p.m. Nov. 7.
Tickets, at $54.50-$80, go on sale at 10 a.m. Oct. 16 at www. sandseventcenter.com, the event center box office, www.Ticketmaster.com, all Ticketmaster outlets or by phone at 800-745-3000.
Burr, whom Rolling Stone magazine called “the undisputed heavyweight champ of rage-fueled humor,” also has an animated series, “F Is For Family,” due to premiere this year on Netflix, also featuring Laura Dern and Justin Long as the Murphy family.
Burr recently co-starred opposite Kevin Costner and Octavia Spencer in the film “Black or White,” which premiered in January. He also just headlined Comedy Central’s annual Night of Too Many Stars Autism benefit.
And Burr is a reular on TV late-night talk shows "The Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon," "The Conan O’Brien Show" and "The Late Show with David Letterman."
The Massachusetts-born Burr, 47, started in comedy in 1992, but got his big break being in the second-season cast on “Chappell’s Show” in 2003. He released his first album, “Emotionally Unavailable,” that year.
On “Breaking Bad,” he played Patrick Kuby in the fourth and fifth seasons, when the show was among the most-watched ever on cable TV and won the Emmy for Outstanding Drama Series both years.
“Let it Go” and “You People Are All The Same” were his first stand-up specials. His most recent special “I’m Sorry You Feel That Way,” premiered on Netflix in December.
He had a role in the 2013 Sandra Bullock-Melissa McCarthy buddy-cop movie “The Heat,” and was in the 2014 film “Walk of Shame” with Elizabeth Banks and previously in “Stand Up Guys” with Al Pacino and Christopher Walken and “Date Night” with Steve Carell and Tina Fey.
Burr’s upcoming animated sitcom is said to be based around his standup and railin about the absurdity of political correctness, rather than to just “Let It Be.”
 In all, he now has released seven comedy discs, with his latest, “Live at Andrew’s House,” released Sept. 30. It is a recording of his 2011 Carnegie Hall performance.
In July, Bill received the Stand-up Comedian of the Year Award from the prestigious Just For Laughs Festival in Montreal.
